item.title: Snooth This: $1M for Wine Review Site
item.dc:creator: Kristen Nicole
item.description: Snooth got another $1 million in angel funding, from its initial investors including Ryan Moynagh and Will Armitage, and a new group of international investors as well. Does this involvement with international investors indicate potential global growth, or a bigger push for international retail partners? This funding comes after the first round [...]
item.content:encoded:
Snooth got another $1 million in angel funding, from its initial investors including Ryan Moynagh and Will Armitage, and a new group of international investors as well. Does this involvement with international investors indicate potential global growth, or a bigger push for international retail partners? This funding comes after the first round of $300,000 nearly a year ago. The funding for Snooth will be used to grow its team, an further integrate retail partners, while adding new partners as well.

As a niche wine review site, Snooth launched early on this year with both retail and peer review attributes, enabling individuals to become experts in their own right, and retail partners to target sales to these fairly passionate users.

Since launching, Snooth has been layering in more social functionality, making it easier to track your wine lists, ratings, and follow the expertise of other users. Wine is unsurprisingly a popular genre for niche social networking, and while sites like Snooth could use even more social, search and recommendation features, it’s clear that niche food, wine and spirits networks are still attractive to users. FoodTube is another that’s recently launched as well.

Share This



Can't see the video? Click here

item.title: ComScore: MySpace Continues Domination of Facebook
item.dc:creator: Mark 'Rizzn' Hopkins
item.description: Gian Flugoni of ComScore released some data the company recently presented at the Forrester Consumer Forum that speaks to the ratios of visitor and ad impression shares between MySpace and Facebook. The numbers are interesting, and the implications admittedly difficult to interpret, but the raw numbers come as no big surprise. MySpace still maintains a [...]
item.content:encoded:
Gian Flugoni of ComScore released some data the company recently presented at the Forrester Consumer Forum that speaks to the ratios of visitor and ad impression shares between MySpace and Facebook. The numbers are interesting, and the implications admittedly difficult to interpret, but the raw numbers come as no big surprise.

MySpace still maintains a clear dominance of the visitor share, with 69% as opposed to Facebook’s 31%. The dominance in advertising is exacerbated by MySpace’s tendency to deliver advertising with a little bit of content to its userbase. The numbers appear crushing to Facebook, in that sense, with roughly 87% going to MySpace and 13% going to Facebook in terms of delivered advertising impressions.

The data was collected in September, so it doesn’t include any new changes to the Facebook or MySpace systems, most notably Facebook’s Beacon or Pages initiatives. Clearly the impact of those will be both difficult to measure and significant, given their infomercial-ish nature.

What is perhaps most interesting is that despite all the interactivity inherent to the Facebook developer program, MySpace visitors still consume an average 1.4 times more pages per visitor than Facebook users.

Yesterday, I also posted a very long diatribe that hopefully will cap off my rants against Project Bacn. If you were masochistic enough to read until the end, you probably remember my slamming of Facebook for walling off their garden so very much. Note that MySpace, while it does have fences around their garden, they are very weak white picket fences (to over-extend the metaphor). Their blogs are RSSified, profiles are publicly indexable, and most content on the site is available without the need to log in.

Most of that content also includes ads. In the run down of the ComScore study, they didn’t specify whether or not they measured non-registered visitors to the MySpace site, but I imagine the passive visitor also contributes significantly to the MySpace bottom line. That’s something Facebook, as of present, can’t claim.

That’s the price of erecting a 20-foot concrete wall around your garden. You may keep the riff-raff out, but it is the riff-raff that pays your bills in the end.

Share This



Can't see the video? Click here

item.title: RIAA’s Lawsuits Possibly Cruel and Unusual
item.dc:creator: Mark 'Rizzn' Hopkins
item.description: I know it is important to stay on top of the RIAA/MPAA War Against Consumers, but doing so sometimes requires quite tedious set-ups to remind everyone (including myself) exactly which case of record industry corn-holing downloaders we’re talking about. The item in the news today is about UMG v. Lindor, in which lawyer Ray Beckerman had [...]
item.content:encoded:
I know it is important to stay on top of the RIAA/MPAA War Against Consumers, but doing so sometimes requires quite tedious set-ups to remind everyone (including myself) exactly which case of record industry corn-holing downloaders we’re talking about.

The item in the news today is about UMG v. Lindor, in which lawyer Ray Beckerman had the brilliant idea of crowd-sourcing the defense of his client, and asked the communities of GrokLaw and SlashDot for help in putting together a deposition and proper defense of his client. After he got past the RIAA-overlord and 1, 2, 3 Profit! jokes, he apparently came back with some really helpful hints, including challenging the constitutionality of the RIAA’s fines on the grounds that $750 - $30,000 a song is “cruel and unusual punishment.”

A court eventually agreed to examine the issue, but the RIAA has fought tooth and nail to keep from actually revealing hard information on how much a download really cost. Magistrate Judge Robert M. Levy has decided that the information is required for the case to proceed, and has ordered the RIAA to turn over the data.

This is a case that looks like it’s going to end up falling the way of the people, if things continue along the path they’re on. It will likely be years before the final effects of the case’s decision will be felt, assuming Beckerman wins, but it could invalidate a host of doomsday scenarios we’ve talked about before in terms of how the average Internet-savvy American citizen is treated as a criminal by the government.

[via TechDirt]

Share This



Can't see the video? Click here

item.title: Picnik Before You Print, with Lexmark
item.dc:creator: Kristen Nicole
item.description: HP isn’t the only printer manufacturer getting involved with the web 2.0 game. Lexmark has teamed up with Picnik for easier editing photos that you’ll be printing. Unfortunately it looks like the easiest access to Picnik for use with Lexmark is by downloading the Lexmark toolbar. It has an access [...]
item.content:encoded:
HP isn’t the only printer manufacturer getting involved with the web 2.0 game. Lexmark has teamed up with Picnik for easier editing photos that you’ll be printing.

Unfortunately it looks like the easiest access to Picnik for use with Lexmark is by downloading the Lexmark toolbar. It has an access button for getting to Picnik directly. If you click on the Photos icon on your Lexmark toolbar, your photos will be pulled up in Picnik’s image-editing application.

It seems like a pretty small step that appeals to a very limited to a small group of users. This could be a trial partnership that could lead to co-branded Lexmark/Picnik browser plug-ins that can be added to any toolbar in Firefox or IE, or even online access to Picnik from Lexmark’s printing software. But as printing companies get more involved with online and web-based tools, they look to make themselves more available in more places.

HP for example has blogging platform plugins for offering printing options for readers that are specific to blogging format needs. With HP’s acquisition of Tabblo, the integrated printing options for the company are quickly expanding. Lexmark is slowly on the same track. Another new way to access Picnik’s tools is through Box.net and its new OpenBox applications.

Share This



Can't see the video? Click here

item.title: BrightCove.TV Shuts Down; Company to Follow?
item.dc:creator: Mark 'Rizzn' Hopkins
item.description: I’ve actually had a love-hate relationship with Brightcove for quite a while. On the one hand, they have the absolute most complex and cool back-end for their video management system that allows for customization of how your videos display. I loved using that. On the other hand, their advertising deals completely sucked [...]
item.content:encoded:
I’ve actually had a love-hate relationship with Brightcove for quite a while. On the one hand, they have the absolute most complex and cool back-end for their video management system that allows for customization of how your videos display. I loved using that. On the other hand, their advertising deals completely sucked canal water (when they were even turned on).

One of the moves I’ve never quite understood, given their focus on complexity and comprehensiveness, was their decision to open up a YouTube clone. Sure, the marginal costs aren’t that much greater, if you’ve got your data hosted in the right way. It doesn’t, though, create the culture of quality content that BrightCove seemed to want to encourage with their complex producer tools.

Those of us with active accounts at BrightCove got an email in September saying that they were moving what is essentially the “unseemly” (read: YouTube-ish) content. Today, though, we get an email saying that it will all be going away, having been up for exactly one month and one week.

As other bloggers have noted, the company has raised $80 million in funding and finally seems to have found its focus. I disagree with that assessment. To make sudden moves and major course corrections as often as BrightCove does indicates a lack of expertise and direction at the top. That’s not to say there isn’t something to be said for being nimble as a company, but when you’ve got $80 million sunk into a venture, nimble and experimentation should fly out the window. You should know what your doing at that point.

That’s the sort of analysis one can easily make just looking at a timeline of the company. When you analyze them after having worked with the company before, though, it looks to be even more shaky. I don’t know the inner-working of deals they have with Marvel.com and Time Magazine Online and how much money BrightCove makes from them, for instance, but I do know the standard offer they give to independent producers. I’m pretty sure I’m NDAed from giving the exact amount, but I can tell you that the only way to make money with it is if you’re using a $12 webcam from WalMart and you have more viewers than the Star Wars kid.

BrightCove is in trouble. They need to beef up their advertising sales, they need to address the management issues, and they need to decide what their company wants to do when it grows up. Otherwise, this company isn’t going to live past puberty.

Share This



Can't see the video? Click here

item.title: Mobile Post to All Your Blogs with Utterz Connections
item.dc:creator: Kristen Nicole
item.description: Utterz, the mobile microblogging tool that came complete with widgets for you to distribute your updates across your social networks, has just released Connections. This lets you post updates to specific sites, including Twitter, Live Journal, Tumblr, TypePad, Wordpress and Blogger, with more on the way. Actually, Utterz already had a plug-in option [...]
item.content:encoded:
Utterz, the mobile microblogging tool that came complete with widgets for you to distribute your updates across your social networks, has just released Connections. This lets you post updates to specific sites, including Twitter, Live Journal, Tumblr, TypePad, Wordpress and Blogger, with more on the way.

Actually, Utterz already had a plug-in option for Wordpress, and the new Connections feature offers an entire section of specific blogging platforms that you can now set up for direct posting from your Utterz account. It’s different than posting to a widget, and all of you bloggers out there with your own online publications know this all too well. Each Connection can be set up in your Utterz account. Choose which one you’d like to activate, and enter your username and password for each respective blogging account. Provide a name and a shortcut for mobile posting directives, and you can then opt to have items automatically posted on Utterz as well.

Unlike the widget offering, Connections lets you pick and choose which sites get which content. This is achieved by using the name you give each associated account, so when you submit a post through Utterz, you’re saying which blogging account it should go to. There’s also a 10 minute delay for auto-posting, which is designed to grant you enough time to add photos and images to an update.

While using Utterz connections won’t be as feature-rich as some of the mobile offerings from each blogging company itself, the benefit of using Utterz is the ability to post to multiple blogging sites that you take part in, from a central location. Many of you won’t be posting the same things to multiple blogs, which leaves little other reason to use Utterz over whatever mobile offering Wordpress and the rest already have, unless you’re very active in Utterz.

Share This



Can't see the video? Click here

item.title: Google Wants Cheap, Renewable Energy. Like, Now.
item.dc:creator: Kristen Nicole
item.description: Google’s getting greener than ever. And setting up more initiatives to find those smart people out there that can take care of the brainiac side of things. The latest: Renewable Energy Cheaper Than Coal. It will focus on advanced solar thermal power, wind power, geothermal systems and other potential technologies that will [...]
item.content:encoded:
Google’s getting greener than ever. And setting up more initiatives to find those smart people out there that can take care of the brainiac side of things. The latest: Renewable Energy Cheaper Than Coal. It will focus on advanced solar thermal power, wind power, geothermal systems and other potential technologies that will save our planet.

This is another project that Google will be spending millions of dollars funding, with its Recharge IT initiative and others having already been launched in the past year. Enough millions to make Al Gore proud. It appears that Google is getting rather impatient with the current state of affairs, and would like the world’s scientists to please hurry up. The good thing about such a high level of funding is of course the ability to allow those working on these efforts to do just that–hurry up.

Half the battle is making the technology accessible and economically viable for regular use in our markets. And as with Google’s other efforts, like the moon rover, providing a great amount of funding gives scientists the wherewithal to make products cheaper and more accessible to others that would like to get involved.

Share This



Can't see the video? Click here

item.title: Open Web Awards: Nominations for Best Large Social Networks
item.dc:creator: Adam Ostrow
item.description: The Open Web Awards are off and running, and over the next few days we will be opening up nominations in 13 categories. The first of those categories is “Mainstream and Large Social Networks” – the sites we’ve all heard of, frequent, and have multi-millions of users. In last year’s social networking awards, Pete wrote [...]
item.content:encoded:
The Open Web Awards are off and running, and over the next few days we will be opening up nominations in 13 categories. The first of those categories is “Mainstream and Large Social Networks” – the sites we’ve all heard of, frequent, and have multi-millions of users.

In last year’s social networking awards, Pete wrote “… we think that Facebook will continue to grow strongly in 2007.” That has certainly been the case, as the network has exploded in popularity since opening up to everyone that wants to join and launching a developer platform. However, recent concerns over its new advertising system and privacy issues have critics questioning the long-term prospects of the site. Meanwhile, MySpace remains #1 in terms of traffic, with other network such as Bebo, Hi5, and LinkedIn all sporting impressive growth in the past year.

With that, we open up the category for nominations. To nominate a social network, leave a comment with the word “NOMINATE” in it. Nominations will remain open until 11:59pm PST on December 4th (next Tuesday). At that point, we will tally up the nominations and enter the second stage of the competition – voting.

Once again, a thank you to our sponsors:

Cohn and Wolfe - Our PR partner and co-producer.

Quintura - Quintura makes you control your web search. You will find what you want as quickly as possible.

RetailMeNot - The RetailMeNot.com community saves you money by sharing 50,000+ coupon codes for 10,000+ stores.

Streakr - Discover more of the web you love together with Streakr.com

item.title: The 1st International Open Web Awards Start Now!
item.dc:creator: Adam Hirsch
item.description: The first ever Open Web Awards have arrived! The Open Web Awards is the first ever online, open collaborative awards event, to recognize the best online communities representing web 2.0. We now have 24 confirmed Blog Partners from several countries from around the world and in several different languages. Over the next week please check [...]
item.content:encoded:
The first ever Open Web Awards have arrived! The Open Web Awards is the first ever online, open collaborative awards event, to recognize the best online communities representing web 2.0. We now have 24 confirmed Blog Partners from several countries from around the world and in several different languages.

Over the next week please check out all of the partner blogs to get involved in their nominations posts. Strike up conversations, nominate your favorites and most importantly debate your choices! Please be on the lookout for nominations posts here on Mashable.com as well.

Now for the big news! First, I would like to unveil the list of the 13 categories that will be floating around:

1. Mainstream and Large Scale Networks
2. Applications and Widgets
3. Social News and Social Bookmarking
4. Social Search
5. Sports and Fitness
6. Photo Sharing
7. Video Sharing
8. Start Pages
9. Places and Events
10. Music
11. Social Shopping
12. Mobile
13. Niche and Miscellaneous Social Networks

Next, I would like to share with our Mashable readers that the first ever Open Web Awards will be concluded with a live awards ceremony in San Francisco on January 10th.

To be a Part of the Open Web Awards
If you are interested in being a Sponsor for the Online Awards and/or the Ceremony or a Blog Partner, please contact me immediately. The deadline for Sponsors is Wednesday, December 5th.

Co-Production and PR by:

The First Online Sponsors


Quintura makes you control your web search. You will find what you want as quickly as possible.


The RetailMeNot.com community saves you money by sharing 50,000+ coupon codes for 10,000+ stores.


Discover more of the web you love together with Streakr.com

item.title: Can Yahoo Structured Search Beat Google?
item.dc:creator: Kristen Nicole
item.description: In an effort to stand out (and then beat) Google, Yahoo may soon be rolling out a structured search for particular keywords, which would give a more informative set of results than just links to websites containing relevant information. While very few details have been released about this possible new search setup, one [...]
item.content:encoded:
In an effort to stand out (and then beat) Google, Yahoo may soon be rolling out a structured search for particular keywords, which would give a more informative set of results than just links to websites containing relevant information.

While very few details have been released about this possible new search setup, one example given is for the search term “mobile phones.” This could return a set of results that offer drop down menus for manufacturer information, brands, technologies, prices and stores. Based on your selections from the drop down menus, your search query will become further tailored to your specific needs.

It’s more of a custom search that borrows some ideas from many that are striving to achieve semantic search, from Grayboxx to Mahalo and Twine. If you look at the basics of what Yahoo is proposing, it appears to be most similar to Grayboxx and Krillion, where users search for certain terms and get a set of results that can be narrowed down for products. Obviously this search setup is more inclined to work better for e-commerce product searches, from a structured level. And it builds on concepts that Yahoo’s been toying with for some time, including the promotion of Yahoo Store search results being included in a pertinent search, or its recent push for an improved Yahoo Local.

So could this in fact help Yahoo differentiate itself from Google, by bringing more value to end users? The idea is useful, especially for those masses of users that aren’t terribly accustomed to online search. But it probably won’t make much of a dent in Google’s dominant market share. Especially after buckling yesterday during Cyber Monday shopping. Ask.com has also been tweaking its search tools in order to offer a broader set of results, giving you song clips and videos that play directly from your query page, and other results that speak towards a structured semantic search as well.

[via macworld]

Share This



Can't see the video? Click here

item.title: Userplane Goes the Meebo Route: 4 New Online TV Partners
item.dc:creator: Kristen Nicole
item.description: Do you ever chat on the phone with your friend while you both watch your favorite program? That’s kind of old school, because now you can chat online. And meshing online chat directly with just about every other online activity has been a progressive movement that’s recently collided with online video–specifically the traditional [...]
item.content:encoded:
Do you ever chat on the phone with your friend while you both watch your favorite program? That’s kind of old school, because now you can chat online. And meshing online chat directly with just about every other online activity has been a progressive movement that’s recently collided with online video–specifically the traditional media sector .

Userplane has teamed up with Channel 4 (UK), The CW, Fuel TV and IFC to offer its customizable chat tools webchat, minichat and webmessenger for their own respective online communities. The idea is built on the concept of an online water cooler, designed to get fans chatting with each other while they watch the show. I’d rather talk to my own friends about my favorite shows, but strangers that are as big a fan as I am will do just fine.

If people are already multi-tasking, why not get them to multi-task on your site? They’ll stick around longer. Joost got the idea, too. It teamed up with Meebo for its own custom chat tools not too long ago. And we’ may be seeing a lot more integrated tools such as those being announced by Userplane today, as more take advantage of the set of OpenSocial APIs launched last week.

Share This



Can't see the video? Click here

item.title: Dating on Plentyoffish - Trading Fees for Scumbags?
item.dc:creator: Kristen Nicole
item.description: Surprise success dating site Plentyoffish has reached a peak in online traffic in the UK, based on a comScore ranking measuring unique visits. Having been around for nearly 5 years, the Canada-based dating site is now reporting numbers higher than Match.com for the month of October. Without the gimmicks, subscription fees and long [...]
item.content:encoded:
Surprise success dating site Plentyoffish has reached a peak in online traffic in the UK, based on a comScore ranking measuring unique visits. Having been around for nearly 5 years, the Canada-based dating site is now reporting numbers higher than Match.com for the month of October.

Without the gimmicks, subscription fees and long applications to fill out, Plentyoffish is pushing its simplistic approach as a new old-school alternative to the psychologically complicated match-making sites that have gained in popularity the past couple of years. We’ve even seen a new wave of match-making tools that are based off of quizzes, recommendations, webcams and even common disinterests, which truly incorporate the web 2.0 nature of current social networking trends but seem to have not picked up enough steam by the demographic that actually turns to online dating as a viable option for life-changing decisions.

Where’s the Love?

I’ve heard some horror stories from my own friends about finding current boyfriends promoting themselves as “single and looking” eHarmony. And finding guys with usernames like GreyGoose35 makes me inclined to feel that the same horror story potential is present on Plentyoffish as well. It almost makes me feel better about subscription fees and long applications, which would deter a good percentage of scum bags out there. At least, that’s what Dr. Phil sells you on. See here for more geeky dating sites.

Share This



Can't see the video? Click here

item.title: Verizon Wireless Opens Network; Will it Join the Open Handset Alliance?
item.dc:creator: Adam Ostrow
item.description: Verizon Wireless has announced that it will be opening up its network, allowing customers to use devices and software not sold by the company. Essentially, this means that any CDMA phone can be designed to work on Verizon’s network (with Sprint being the other large CDMA carrier in the US), and customers will have [...]
item.content:encoded:
Verizon Wireless has announced that it will be opening up its network, allowing customers to use devices and software not sold by the company. Essentially, this means that any CDMA phone can be designed to work on Verizon’s network (with Sprint being the other large CDMA carrier in the US), and customers will have a wider selection of operating systems and software they can use.

Previously, Verizon and other carriers have pre-packaged their phones with software, which mobile developers often pay them to carry. With this new direction, Verizon will publish standards that developers can use to build applications that will run on their network.

The move begs the question of whether Verizon will imminently join the Google-led Open Handset Alliance.
Such a move was rumored before the alliance and the Android operating system were announced, but has not yet come to fruition.

T-Mobile has already joined up and will be releasing Android-based handsets in 2008. With today’s move, Verizon looks to be giving up a short-term revenue stream in favor of the long-term movement towards a more open wireless environment, so joining up with Google is likely the next step.

[via WSJ]

Share This



Can't see the video? Click here

item.title: Social Networking Conference Miami: Register Now and Save $220
item.dc:creator: Adam Ostrow
item.description: We’re proud to announce that Mashable is a media sponsor for the upcoming Social Networking Conference in beautiful Miami, FL. The event takes place January 31-February 1, and if you register before November 30th, you can save $220. Topics covered include: global business strategies for social networking, mobile, revenue models, social media marketing, [...]
item.content:encoded:
We’re proud to announce that Mashable is a media sponsor for the upcoming Social Networking Conference in beautiful Miami, FL. The event takes place January 31-February 1, and if you register before November 30th, you can save $220.

Topics covered include: global business strategies for social networking, mobile, revenue models, social media marketing, venture capital for social networking and online personals, new technologies, partnerships, legal issues and payments.

Speakers include RockYou, Pixsy, Research In Motion, and many others.

And, who doesn’t want to go to Miami in the middle of winter?

item.title: Create Silly Animations With Gizmoz “Be A Star”
item.dc:creator: Stan Schroeder
item.description: Gizmoz takes its 3D avatar concept a bit further with a new service called Be A Star, which lets you create mini-movies, starring avatars with your (or your friends’) faces. The movies are quite funny and/or cool, as expected: two examples are self-defense lesson with bad Russian overdub and a huge skateboard jump. The [...]
item.content:encoded:
Gizmoz takes its 3D avatar concept a bit further with a new service called Be A Star, which lets you create mini-movies, starring avatars with your (or your friends’) faces. The movies are quite funny and/or cool, as expected: two examples are self-defense lesson with bad Russian overdub and a huge skateboard jump.

The concept is simple: upload a photo of your face, and - with your help - Gizmoz will convert it into a talking 3D head, which is then glued to the avatars in the movies. Of course, the resulting animations, which are 30 - 60 seconds long, can be embedded on a blog or social networking profiles, uploaded to video site, posted to any web site, or shared by e-mail.

We’ve seen applications like this before; one example is PlayMyGame, which lets you create little interactive games with your avatars. This is one of those ideas that seem certain to become megapopular, especially amongst the MySpace crowd, but we’re not really sure they are. I guess that the old law about the people who create (the minority) and the people who consume (the majority) applies here; it’s really hard to make the majority move their ass and do something, while the creators will find a way to create stuff even without advanced tools like these.

Share This



Can't see the video? Click here

item.title: UK TV Houses Join To Create Online Video On Demand Service
item.dc:creator: Stan Schroeder
item.description: BBC, ITV and Channel 4 will launch a joint online on-demand video service in 2008, providing hundreds of hours of TV program, all in one place. The content offered by the currently unnamed service (code name being Kangaroo) will include over 10.000 hours of program, including current shows and archive materials. Furthermore, the three production [...]
item.content:encoded:
BBC, ITV and Channel 4 will launch a joint online on-demand video service in 2008, providing hundreds of hours of TV program, all in one place. The content offered by the currently unnamed service (code name being Kangaroo) will include over 10.000 hours of program, including current shows and archive materials. Furthermore, the three production houses hope to have other content providers join their service.

Presently, these three broadcasters each have their own separate VoD services: BBC’s iPlayer, ITV’s catch-up and Channel 4oD will coexist with the new service after the launch. The new service can thus be described as an aggregator of all this content.

Users will be able to download, stream, rent and purchase content over the Internet, while expansion to other platforms is planned.

“The new service will contain some of the very best of the UK’s content for consumers to view in one place, which will be both easy to use and great fun” said John Smith, chief executive of BBC Worldwide.

Several questions with services such as this, of course, are inevitable. One is DRM. I doubt that consumers will welcome yet another shoving of DRM-infected content down their throats, although the idea of having thousands of hours of TV available on-demand sounds terrific. The other is availability: will the content be available to anyone, or only UK customers? Then, there’s quality, which will hopefully go all the way up to HD.

I don’t have answers to these questions now, but I have a pointer: BBC’s iPlayer has had incompatibility problems with many machines, it has DRM, and it doesn’t work outside of the UK. Enough said.

[via BBC and Guardian]

Share This



Can't see the video? Click here

item.title: coComment Yourself on Facebook
item.dc:creator: Kristen Nicole
item.description: coComment has found another way to let you follow your comments across the web. It has two new Facebook applications that will track and display the comments from blogs and websites that you participate in. One app is for individual users, while the other is for publishers. So no matter what [...]
item.content:encoded:
coComment has found another way to let you follow your comments across the web. It has two new Facebook applications that will track and display the comments from blogs and websites that you participate in. One app is for individual users, while the other is for publishers. So no matter what your purpose behind comment-tracking, you can share it with friends on Facebook.

The good thing about the application designed for individual users is the ability to customize which blogs’ comments display in the app. This of course will also be displayed on your profile, so all your friends can see your comments from across the web. Now, setting up the Facebook apps for coComment is a different story. It’s not so easy if you don’t already have a coComment account, and of course you’ll need to register and install the coComment application prior to starting with your app on Facebook.

So is it worth the trouble? The hope is to find new places to congregate your comments, and get friends more interested in all those smart things you say on other people’s blogs. But I’m actually less inclined to read comments when they’re “floating” around without context. At the very least, I do like the idea of having access to my aggregated comments available on Facebook.

Share This

item.dc:creator: Stan Schroeder
item.description: Wired has a new thing going on over at video.wired.com. For this purpose, they’ve hired Annaliza Savage of CrankyGeeks fame, which has previously worked for Ziff Davis. This hasn’t got a lot to do with Wired, but it seems that things aren’t looking good at Ziff Davis Media; several months ago, Patrick Norton left them [...]
item.content:encoded:
Wired has a new thing going on over at video.wired.com. For this purpose, they’ve hired Annaliza Savage of CrankyGeeks fame, which has previously worked for Ziff Davis. This hasn’t got a lot to do with Wired, but it seems that things aren’t looking good at Ziff Davis Media; several months ago, Patrick Norton left them and joined Revision3.

As far as the actual site goes, don’t expect too much. The only thing you will find online at this point are some excerpts from a show called Wired Science. Check out a cool one with some rocketbelt footage below.

[via NewTeeVee]

Share This



Can't see the video? Click here

item.title: The War On BitTorrent Reaches Iceland
item.dc:creator: Stan Schroeder
item.description: There was a time when BitTorrent trackers were a no-no thing in the US, but you could have had one in Europe without much trouble. That time is now gone, as the joint efforts of various anti-piracy organizations are taking down the big European BitTorrent trackers one by one. The last in line is Torrent.is, [...]
item.content:encoded:
There was a time when BitTorrent trackers were a no-no thing in the US, but you could have had one in Europe without much trouble. That time is now gone, as the joint efforts of various anti-piracy organizations are taking down the big European BitTorrent trackers one by one.

The last in line is Torrent.is, which has been taken down by the regional District Commissioners office, upon the request of Iceland’s MPAA, SMAIS, and three other anti-piracy organizations. SMAIS also requested seizure of all hardware related to Torrent.is, but this request was denied. Torrent.is was founded in May 2006 and it was the biggest private BitTorrent tracker in Iceland with 26.500 users.

The head admin at Torrent.is, Svavar Kjarrval, is determined to change this decision. “I’m going to fight this as far as I possibly can. The general public seems to be on our side.” They certainly are, since they’ve been sending death threats and hatemail to SMAIS official, Snæbjörn Steingrímsson, known as one of the leaders in the war against file sharing in Iceland.

Things are grim for BitTorrent and file sharing in general. Mark wrote a fantastic piece on this topic earlier today. To me, the general stance by the authorities seems to be: well, there may be some bad stuff going on in there, so we’re just going to destroy the whole thing. Pressure from big business seems to be a big enough stick to make this an easy decision, but it shouldn’t be. By blocking BitTorrent, you’re not just blocking “illegal file sharing”; you’re blocking “sharing” altogether. Let’s hope that not all European countries will submit to this line of thinking.

[via TorrentFreak]

Share This



Can't see the video? Click here

item.title: Why Facebook’s Modus Operandi Matters
item.dc:creator: Mark 'Rizzn' Hopkins
item.description: There are a number of major, show stopping problems that I see with the Kindle. As you know, I was critical of the Kindle before being critical of the Kindle was cool. In addition to the ugliness, craptastic business model and price as well as the lack of unit features I noted from the leaked [...]
item.content:encoded:
There are a number of major, show stopping problems that I see with the Kindle. As you know, I was critical of the Kindle before being critical of the Kindle was cool. In addition to the ugliness, craptastic business model and price as well as the lack of unit features I noted from the leaked data the Friday before its release, I’ve come to realize that there is one particularly good reason to hate the Kindle, pointed out by Scoble and enumerated by Fred at A VC:

I Don’t Want To Consume Media That I Can’t Interact With.

That’s the bottom line. When I come into contact with media, I want to do something with it. Tag it, post it, reply to it, comment on it, favorite it, share it, gift it, quote it, piss on it, whatever.

And that’s one of Scoble’s big beefs with the Kindle.

When are people going to understand that digital media, be it a book, a song, a film, an article, or whatever else, is not passive media. That was analog’s gig.

Since my initial article, there have been approximately two trillion blog posts on the matter. Fortunately for you, I’m not going to make it two trillion and one. The illustration of what’s wrong with the Kindle is a bit of what’s wrong with Facebook, and I think what may be at the root of why I’m having such a hard time gaining value from it. I’ve been purposely avoiding bagging further on Facebook, because I know that everyone must think I’m some sort of cranky anti-social geek at this point.

I promise that at one point I actually did like Facebook and what it provided. My opinion sharply turned once Project Bacn was announced, and one of the Mashable readers called me on it quite insightfully at the time, and caused me to elaborate on what it was that I saw as being horribly wrong with the Project Bacn initiative (culled from the comments of this post):.

I’m obviously not anti-advertising or anti-social network. I write for a social networking blog that’s advertiser supported (and therefore that is what pays my bills). I think my problem comes in when companies that are proving time and time again to be irresponsible with the privacy of my personal data continue to ask for more and more of my personal data, and hope that I’ll accept this without qualm.

The reason that when Google goes off in left field when it comes to privacy and seems to get a pass is that they’ve been very very careful about what the do and don’t disclose in the way of user’s data.

Facebook is grasping at straws in terms of monetization and attempting to justify their over-valuation. They’ve sold out their user base, and turned their entire system into a spam factory in terms of what the users do and don’t buy or do off-site. You must go out to the individual many initial partners and hunt through their settings to find the button that turns off sending of data to Facebook. What makes the problem even further compounded is that they will be adding future partners to this list as well. I’m sure we, who follow the tech blogosphere, might know fairly quickly. Those that just use these systems instead of read about them daily might not know for quite a while.

If Facebook gave me a discount on purchases at eBay because they’re using that purchase to advertise to all my social circle, perhaps I’d like project beacon a bit more. If Facebook actually did something far reaching with social ads beyond pattern matching (and actually dig deep into behavioral targeting and allow non-Facebook sites to benefit ala AdSense), I’d consider it a bit more innovative.

But because they’re willing to mortgage their user base at every turn, and resell every bit of data they can, I see them as little better than shady downtown used car salesman, not as responsible, innovative members of the tech community.

Going back to the context of what Fred touched on with the Kindle, I think what may anger me the most about Project Bacn is that it adds no value to the equation, at least not for me as the user. It adds no value because I must disrupt my daily routine to interact with my media. I’m sure that the idea for Facebook is to bring the world inside it’s walled garden, but that’s just not happening, at the moment. I can’t blog and reasonably expect to go through my many RSS feeds and collaboratively edit documents with the team from within Facebook.

Simply put, Facebook won’t come to me and be interactive, and I doesn’t have the ability to let me exist completely within it. My interactions with the web are well documented by my various apps within Facebook, but it still has very little to offer me that can rival my toolbox outside the system.
Instead of bridging that functionality gap, Facebook has decided that I and my offsite actions online have been commoditized for public consumption and marketing for those that can stay inside the walled garden. Doc Searls says that he can forgive Facebook for reaching for the brass ring since Project Bacn is the “Holy Grail”; this to me smacks of appeasement and far too conciliatory. Facebook is sitting on top of a mountain of data, and while it may not be worth $15 Billion, it sure isn’t worthless either. There are a hundred other ways to creatively monetize it (to much more accolade in the techosphere).

If, for instance they had decided to the more intuitive route (given the trend for open-ness these days), and start RSS-ifying their system up, a brand new world of monetizable property could have been created. I would love to have my mini-feed and personal news feed RSS-ified, even if it meant including periodic ads inserted in the RSS stream. You see, that’s giving value back to me; it creates something that I can use outside of the walled garden, and it works for Facebook beneficially in a number of ways.

Not only do they have another monetizable property in general to work with, they’ve also a hook to keep bringing me back to the system. As I work to integrate and apply all the usefulness of what an RSSified set of Facebook feeds would bring to my life, I’m going to need to go back to Facebook regularly to tweak the settings so as to get them just right. Not to mention the hyper-precision targeting they would have, even using simple keyword matching. Best of all, I choose who I wish to share my RSS feed with. If I choose to use the RSS feed for personal reasons in my own reader or whether I choose to publish it somewhere in some form or fashion - it is left up to me. That’s empowering me as a user and giving me value while Facebook takes advantage of it’s unique mountain of data in a way no one else can.

Or they could have focused on their video content. For a time Ken Rutkowski and Robert Scoble (and now, I understand, the Gilmore Gang?) have been creating Facebook-exclusive video content. There is certainly no shortage of ways to monetize that; in fact some say an over-abundance of ways.

Or they could have focused on any other number of aspects of the system that could be enhanced and simultaneously monetized. The problem is, they didn’t. Their big revolutionary announcement was turning its user base into unpaid spokespersons for Facebook’s sponsors. Zuckerberg can try as he might to explain it away as part of the contract of having a free site, but the fact remains that there are at least a hundred new sites a month cropping up with similar functionality to Facebook.

If Facebook can’t figure out a way to make money while adding value, the users will find a network that can.

Share This



Can't see the video? Click here

item.title: FoodTube Has Plenty of Videos, But No Direction
item.dc:creator: Kristen Nicole
item.description: FoodTube.net is a recently launched site that is an online video aggregator for just that: clips about food. Even though the aesthetics of the sire aren’t all that appealing, it’s actually got all the functionality it needs. There are video-sharing capabilities, tagging and embed options, the ability to create channels, RSS subscriptions [...]
item.content:encoded:
FoodTube.net is a recently launched site that is an online video aggregator for just that: clips about food. Even though the aesthetics of the sire aren’t all that appealing, it’s actually got all the functionality it needs. There are video-sharing capabilities, tagging and embed options, the ability to create channels, RSS subscriptions for individual users, and all the other obligatory social networking tools.

Adding clips can be done by direct uploads from your computer or mobile phone, or importing from various video-sharing networks like YouTube. One interesting feature found along the right side of the page is the inclusion of video thumbnails for restaurants, with their address showing beneath each thumbnail. These almost look like video ads combined with Google ads, and I’m wondering if FoodTube is actually reserving this space for just that type of advertising. If it’s not, it might as well.

What FoodTube is missing, however, is a decent search and filtering option. With its niche being somewhat broad, encompassing food videos in general, the site is different from a wine niche site, iFoods or VideoJug, which specializes in how-to videos. Even GroupRecipes, which has a video section, has a focus on cooking and preparation.

On FoodTube, you’ll find clips that simply tour a restaurant, as well as those that teach you how to cook, or make drinks, etc. So starting with a basic recommendation option for getting users to more actively search the site would be good, and better search and filter options can be built up from there.

[via appscout]

Share This



Can't see the video? Click here

item.title: Would You Watch Commercials Like Music Videos?
item.dc:creator: Kristen Nicole
item.description: We’ve all had that moment when we thought that new Snickers commercial with the Viking and the Pilgrim was so funny that we wished someone had been there to see it with us. We might spend all of 85 seconds searching YouTube for a pirated (or even promotional) clip of the commercial to [...]
item.content:encoded:
We’ve all had that moment when we thought that new Snickers commercial with the Viking and the Pilgrim was so funny that we wished someone had been there to see it with us. We might spend all of 85 seconds searching YouTube for a pirated (or even promotional) clip of the commercial to send it to friends. But we won’t be poring over the boob tube waiting for our favorite programs to be interrupted in hopes of catching that commercial again.

So with Firebrand’s manifesto wildly supporting its love for commercials, you’d think that its network would have more than a handful of video content, for those rare occasions where we do want to find that funny television ad. But since it doesn’t, I find myself scratching my head trying to figure out why Microsoft, NBC Universal and GE think this was a good investment (amount undisclosed).

I can understand these larger companies being interested in the direction of online video ads, or the use of TV ads for an online network. We saw the launching of other networks dedicated to advertisements from larger broadcast and cable networks, like TBS. One downfall with networks launching ads such is this is the fact that you’ll get a somewhat limited array of advertisements. The same could go for Firebrand, and it’s already very short on content. Not to mention the site is too heavy with Flash for quick viewing, and difficult to navigate as well.

So I figure that Firebrand, and its new investors has something up its sleeve. So far, Firebrand’s angle is the promotion of quality commercials that are presented in the same manner as you’d see music videos on MTV2. It’s also debuting on the ION Network, which very much offers its content up as an actual program that you watch like any other. But I have to admit, I’m still scratching my head on this one.

[via podcasting news]

Share This



Can't see the video? Click here

item.title: GDrive is Here; This Time We’re Not Kidding…
item.dc:creator: Mark 'Rizzn' Hopkins
item.description: … at least we hope not. According to the Journal, Google is finally set to release the long rumored, never released GDrive. A Google spokeswoman declined to comment on specific online storage plans aside from “storage is an important component of making Web [applications] fit easily into consumers’ and business users’ lives.” As it has [...]
item.content:encoded:
… at least we hope not. According to the Journal, Google is finally set to release the long rumored, never released GDrive. A Google spokeswoman declined to comment on specific online storage plans aside from “storage is an important component of making Web [applications] fit easily into consumers’ and business users’ lives.”

As it has been noted before, Google already offers a number of online storage options within many of its current suite of online tools, allowing users to store email, photos, office documents and blog posts. The new storage service will end up tying together some of the services through a single search box, instead of having to switch between the different system interfaces (or download client side solutions such as Google Desktop).

Pricing on the tool is not yet announced, but WSJ indicates that there will be likely free and paid versions available.

There is no doubt that this is probably one of the most anticipated tools since the gPhone, so much so that it has prompted a number of hacks to the GMail system to simulate the imagined functionality of the system. It is far more likely, though, that when the GDrive system does come to fruition that it will end up working a lot more like an overlay to existing file management utilities, as opposed to an extension to the local file system on the client computer.

Share This



Can't see the video? Click here

item.title: Comics Sketch is a Glorified Graffiti Tool
item.dc:creator: Kristen Nicole
item.description: Comics Sketch is a new artists community for users to create their own comic books. It’s not like ZingFu or Comeeko, where comic strips are automatically created for you with your photos and some text insertion. But it’s not like a great piece of software that gives you several options for making [...]
item.content:encoded:
Comics Sketch is a new artists community for users to create their own comic books. It’s not like ZingFu or Comeeko, where comic strips are automatically created for you with your photos and some text insertion. But it’s not like a great piece of software that gives you several options for making comic book illustrations either.

It’s more like a glorified Graffiti application that became popular on Facebook, enabling you to make freehand illustrations to be shared with the community. And there are no text options, so any captions you’d like to add to your comic would have to be freehand as well. The only interesting feature about Comics Sketch’s site is the way it “draws” the comics once you load a strip to view.

The limitations of the image creation tools really hurt the potential of Comics Sketch for now, but seeing the inactive features throughout the site, such as exportation, it’s clear that Comics Sketch is planning on adding several more options for users to take advantage of. Hopefully the improvement of image creation tools is at the top of its task list.

With the problems going on with the comic industry, copyright infringement and the epic battle of traditional media taking its place in online sectors, a community like Comics Sketch could appeal to a wide range of comic lovers, offering more tools for a controlled expression of the art they enjoy and providing additional outlets for the sharing of this type of media. Perhaps the comic book industry could get more involved with a site like Comics Sketch for this very purpose.

[via webware]

Share This



Can't see the video? Click here

item.title: Call In Your Amazon Orders with Jott
item.dc:creator: Kristen Nicole
item.description: Jott, the voice messaging tool that’s slowly integrating itself into social networking in various and unique ways, is getting ready to launch a service for Amazon users. Dial the number 1-866-JOTT-123, and say “Amazon.” You’ll then be prompted to say the name of the product you’d like to remind yourself to spend money [...]
item.content:encoded:
Jott, the voice messaging tool that’s slowly integrating itself into social networking in various and unique ways, is getting ready to launch a service for Amazon users. Dial the number 1-866-JOTT-123, and say “Amazon.” You’ll then be prompted to say the name of the product you’d like to remind yourself to spend money on later.

It’s a niche take on shopping lists if I ever heard one. The items you list by voice using Jott’s service will be added to your wish list if you’d like to remember it for yourself. Otherwise, you can add it to your shopping cart if you’re buying it for someone else. So will you be using it?

It’s a very direct way to make your Amazon wish lists, and Jott is good for finding interesting ways to offer its service for use with other popular services and trends, like its tools for sending voice messages to presidential candidates. Need an even easier way to (not) remember to buy products on Amazon? It’s got a new subscription service for auto-payments and auto-delivery for groceries.

Share This



Can't see the video? Click here

item.title: Xbox 360: Social Networking Platform
item.dc:creator: Mark 'Rizzn' Hopkins
item.description: Fans of the Xbox 360 will notice their systems update on December 4th, and according to reports will now allow a social networking feature called “Friends of Friends.” There exists currently within the Xbox live framework the ability to maintain a list of friends, presumably regular gaming partners. The new update will extend that functionality [...]
item.content:encoded:
Fans of the Xbox 360 will notice their systems update on December 4th, and according to reports will now allow a social networking feature called “Friends of Friends.” There exists currently within the Xbox live framework the ability to maintain a list of friends, presumably regular gaming partners.

The new update will extend that functionality to allow several levels of visibility of your friend list to others. Those 13 and up will be allowed the ability to show their friends who else is on their list. Adults will be able to make their friends list public. For those under 13, all friend lists will remain blocked.

What’s also somewhat interesting is how Microsoft is billing this update in their press releases, saying that the feature can be used as a tool to “find old friends or connect with new ones within the community of more the eight million people.” Of course, a community of eight million does not a social networking powerhouse make, but it ain’t no slouch either. I doubt there will be much use in the social network (at least initially) beyond being able to scope out other potential game-mates.

But as Microsoft rounds out more of these features, one has to wonder at what point the integration with Facebook will start. Microsoft obviously invested at a fairly steep valuation, there is clearly open hooks in the Facebook system for it. With Facebook and Xbox being the two clearly successful products that Microsoft have on the market at the moment (especially in light of the foibles of Vista highlighted today at Devil Mountain Software), you’d think they’d want to leverage that success even further.

[via Kotaku]

Share This



Can't see the video? Click here

item.title: Intuit Buys Homestead Technologies for $170M
item.dc:creator: Kristen Nicole
item.description: Intuit, the company behind QuickBooks, Quicken and TurboTax software, has acquired Homestead Technologies for about $170 million. As Homestead offers website creation tools and other e-commerce and marketing products made for online use, the combination of Intuit and Homestead will present opportunities for Homestead’s technologies to be used for small businesses both internally [...]
item.content:encoded:
Intuit, the company behind QuickBooks, Quicken and TurboTax software, has acquired Homestead Technologies for about $170 million. As Homestead offers website creation tools and other e-commerce and marketing products made for online use, the combination of Intuit and Homestead will present opportunities for Homestead’s technologies to be used for small businesses both internally and with direct interaction with customers.

The plan is to basically offer a suite of solutions for companies looking for an integrated option to extend their businesses into the online sector, reach out to customers and retain them as well. Intuit had already been making some moves towards offering more self-administrative tools for business owners with the launch of services like their involvement with the online service for Quicken.

The company also already has a partnership with Google, which should be another advantage for the web-based tools and Google’s ongoing initiative. With the combination of Intuit and Homestead, these web-based tools move even further into the realm of Salesforce, but could present another level of competition for services like Upspring that are using the social networking angle for the promotion of businesses online.

Share This



Can't see the video? Click here

item.title: Facebook App Sees Small Selling Price. What’s it Really Worth?
item.dc:creator: Kristen Nicole
item.description: A Facebook application called Advent Calendar (one of a handful) had put itself up for sale on eBay last week, but hasn’t gotten more than $7,099 by the final bidding time. That wasn’t enough to meet the reserve, and gives a rather dismal outlook to the overall value of Facebook apps. While there [...]
item.content:encoded:
A Facebook application called Advent Calendar (one of a handful) had put itself up for sale on eBay last week, but hasn’t gotten more than $7,099 by the final bidding time. That wasn’t enough to meet the reserve, and gives a rather dismal outlook to the overall value of Facebook apps. While there has been a lot of interest in Facebook’s platform and the subsequent applications on the investment end, no applications have seemed to fetch a large acquisition price.

This seems to be for several reasons, most of which seem to be associated with the current market. But I don’t really have to state the obvious when it comes to this particular Advent Calendar application that’s been put up for sale–how do you monetize such an application that can only be used for 24 days of the year?

Nevertheless, this is the second company in the past week to seek a buyout in time for the holidays. DivShare has kept the details of its “for sale” status pretty under wraps, but a lot of speculation regarding its selling potential has been swirling around as well. But when it comes to the Advent Calendar application, it’s a rather unique situation, considering the newness of applications, the “market” and the rest of the world joining in on the open bandwagon.

[via allfacebook]

Share This



Can't see the video? Click here

item.title: YouTube and UStream Go Political
item.dc:creator: Mark 'Rizzn' Hopkins
item.description: The Web 2.0 political pressure cooker is heating up this week with several high profile events taking place. Coming up on Wednesday is the much hyped CNN-YouTube Republican debate, with @AndersonCooper moderating. There have been a number of great videos rising through the ranks that I’ve watched, but I’m not ruling out the possibility of [...]
item.content:encoded:
The Web 2.0 political pressure cooker is heating up this week with several high profile events taking place. Coming up on Wednesday is the much hyped CNN-YouTube Republican debate, with @AndersonCooper moderating. There have been a number of great videos rising through the ranks that I’ve watched, but I’m not ruling out the possibility of a snowman repeat incident, as the questions are selected by the editorial staff, not a democratic process as in the 10Questions debates.

Meanwhile, at the live version of YouTube, UStream plays host to several important presidential wannabes this week, starting tomorrow with Barrack Obama’s all-day New Hampshire event. There, Senator B. Hussein Obama will conclude a three-day trip to New Hampshire tomorrow, with a foreign policy forum in Portsmouth to be streamed live via UStream.

I spoke with Brad Hunstable today (founder of UStream), and he gave me a bit more detail about the upcoming political focus at UStream. While the dialogue may be open with the meetspace participants of the event, very little interaction is expected to take place with participants in the chat room. None-the-less, it should be an interesting event to watch (that is, if you’re a true political junky), as a fair number of Obama’s top advisers will be present at the event as well, including Richard Danzig and Tony Lake (who both served as advisers to the President during the Clinton years) and Admiral John Hutson.

This event, however, will serve as a prelude to several other confirmed political events, Brad told me, taking place this week. Not only will Democratic Presidential candidate Dennis Kucinich will continue his regular UStream broadcasts on the 28th, the day of the Republican debate, but several as of yet un-named Republican candidates will interact directly by way of the chat room on UStream as well, according to Hunstable.

The political events hosted so far on UStream and YouTube have been wildly successful, certainly so compared with the lackluster response the Facebook political moves have received so far. What is important is that not only are the political candidates going through the motions of appearing to understand how social media works, several candidates are actually using social media to engage their potential constituents - and that’s forward progress in today’s pre-packaged political day and age.

Share This



Can't see the video? Click here
